Placenta

Placenta . Drugs pass a lipid bilayer to cross the placenta.

Lipid solubility : Hydrophilic drugs transfer slowly through sparse aqueous channels. Rate is according to Fick’s law of diffusion . Lipophilic drugs cross freely, so delivery to the foetus is essentially determined by placental blood flow.

Protein binding : highly protein-bound drugs in plasma have a relatively low ‘free’ concentration to diffuse across the placenta

Ionisation : highly ionised molecules do not cross. ‘Ion trapping’ occurs when a molecule becomes ionised on the more acidic foetal side of the placenta.
